title: Pair of Linear Equations in Two Variables

subtopics.title: Introduction to Pair of Linear Equations
subtopics.content:
Introduction

A linear equation in two variables is an equation of the form:

ax + by + c = 0

where a, b, c are real numbers, and a, b are not both zero.

Examples:

2x + 3y = 6

x - y + 5 = 0

A pair of linear equations in two variables consists of two such equations. The solution is the pair (x,y) that satisfies both equations simultaneously. Graphically, the solution represents the point of intersection of two lines.

subtopics.title: Forms of Linear Equations
subtopics.content:
Forms of Linear Equations

General form: a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0, a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0

Each equation represents a straight line in the coordinate plane.

subtopics.title: Consistency of a Pair of Equations
subtopics.content:
Consistency of a Pair of Equations

Depending on the relationship between the two lines:

  • Consistent (unique solution) – Two lines intersect at one point. a₁/a₂ ≠ b₁/b₂
  • Consistent (infinitely many solutions) – Two lines coincide. a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ = c₁/c₂
  • Inconsistent (no solution) – Two lines are parallel. a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ ≠ c₁/c₂

subtopics.title: Methods of Solving
subtopics.content:
Methods of Solving

Graphical Method – Plot the two lines and find intersection.

Substitution Method – Solve one equation for a variable, substitute in the other.

Elimination Method – Multiply equations if needed, then add/subtract to eliminate a variable.

Cross-Multiplication Method – For equations:

a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0, a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0

The solution is:

x/(b₁c₂ - b₂c₁) = y/(c₁a₂ - c₂a₁) = 1/(a₁b₂ - a₂b₁)

questions.question: General form of linear equation in two variables:
questions.explanation: The general form of a linear equation in two variables is ax + by + c = 0, where a, b, and c are real numbers and a, b are not both zero.

questions.question: Equations 2x+3y=7, 4x+6y=14 represent:
questions.explanation: The second equation is exactly twice the first equation (4x+6y=14 is 2(2x+3y=7)). So they represent the same line, hence coincident lines.

questions.question: If lines are parallel, solutions =
questions.explanation: Parallel lines never intersect, so there is no point (x,y) that satisfies both equations simultaneously. Hence, no solution.

questions.question: Equations 3x+2y=5, 6x+4y=10 →
questions.explanation: The second equation is exactly twice the first equation (6x+4y=10 is 2(3x+2y=5)). So they represent the same line, hence infinitely many solutions.

questions.question: Which method involves plotting?
questions.explanation: The graphical method involves plotting the lines on a coordinate plane and finding their point of intersection.

questions.question: Solve: x+y=10, x–y=2 →
questions.explanation: Adding the equations: (x+y)+(x-y) = 10+2 → 2x = 12 → x = 6. Substituting in first equation: 6+y = 10 → y = 4. So solution is (6,4).

questions.question: For x+2y–5=0, 3x+6y–15=0 →
questions.explanation: The second equation is exactly 3 times the first equation (3x+6y–15 = 3(x+2y–5)). So they represent the same line, hence coincident lines.

questions.question: Condition for inconsistency:
questions.explanation: A pair of linear equations is inconsistent (no solution) when the lines are parallel, which happens when a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ ≠ c₁/c₂.

questions.question: Solve: x+y=5, x–y=1 →
questions.explanation: Adding the equations: (x+y)+(x-y) = 5+1 → 2x = 6 → x = 3. Substituting in first equation: 3+y = 5 → y = 2. So solution is (3,2).

questions.question: Pair representing coincident lines:
questions.explanation: The second equation 2x–2y=6 is exactly 2 times the first equation x–y=3. So they represent the same line, hence coincident lines.
